ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An opportunity to engage more deeply with Bach's music.
The course is tailored to the individual. I worked toward learning, understanding, and performing multiple pieces of the piano repertoire.

By taking this course, I was able to develop both my foundational music skills (i.e., breathwork, air support, intonation, etc.) alongside more advanced practices (i.e., altissimo, enhanced technicality, vocal transcription, etc.). I grew significantly as a musician, developed more effective practice habits, and learned to identify my strengths and weaknesses.
improved musicianship, taught me to think critically about what recordings I was listening to and what interpretation(s) I was adopting and why, honed skills as a clarinetist
I worked in depth on repertoire and had consistent, in depth feedback that improved my playing.
Improve clarinetistry and musicianship.
Practice skills, violin technique, and musicality
How to play the saxophone better
I greatly improved my vocal technique and learned new music.
This course offered me a deeper musical understanding--including technical, lyrical, and theory knowledge.
I learned different musical skills, including how to manipulate vibrato and become more expressive.
Piano performance skills
My tone improved so much! I was also able to learn a lot of previously unfamiliar repertoire.

I was able to make significant progress in my saxophone playing this semester. I think that my biggest leaps came in interpretation, phrasing, and tone. It was wonderful to study repertoire with depth and to transcribe vocal performances. I feel so lucky to be able to take these music lessons and to study with Prof. Koffman.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was excellent in that it provided me substantial opportunities to hone my skills as a musician, and the final recital requirement gave me a tangible goal to work towards. In the future, I think the course would benefit from a more concrete lesson plan that is determined and presented at the beginning of the semester. This gives the student a better understanding of each lesson's importance and goal in a broader context.
Learning from grad students is great, but it would be amazing if wind/brass players can study with YSM faculty the way string players can.
overall was a great experience, I had fun and learned a lot. obviously it would have been nice to have these lessons in person but we made the most of the online experience!
This is a fantastic course, and an amazing way to improve musicianship

Strengths: I was able to mold this course in whatever way I wanted to improve my singing and technique.
Weaknesses: I wish there was enough lessons in this program to fill the semester, not just 10 lessons.

Strengths: The course is on a person-by-person basis so it was really whatever you made of it. As such, the music instruction was very strong and enjoyable.

Weakness: N/A
Online lessons are not effective

I enjoyed the weekly lessons, and I especially enjoyed performing for my peers and receiving feedback from them. Unfortunately, virtual lessons with Zoom audio quality can be distracting, given connection problems.
I had a great experience with my YSM professor as I was preparing for a competition, and she was in full support of it every lesson.

Strengths: First of all, it is an incredible opportunity and a great privilege to take lessons at no cost. The quality of the instruction, even on Zoom, is fantastic, and the resources that Yale provided (microphones and practice spaces in my case) really helped during the pandemic. 

Weaknesses: We're on the tail end (hopefully) of the pandemic now, but if virtual instruction continues, it would be helpful to have even more resources for students who cannot practice in their dorm rooms. In particular, it would have been helpful to have lockers in the School of Music in which I could store my instruments. Carrying two fairly large instruments across campus to practice every day was physically difficult and a disincentive to regular practicing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: By nature, it was difficult to adequately communicate with my instructor over Zoom. There were frequent connectivity issues and lag, but this was inevitable and can only be fixed by scrapping the Zoom format entirely and returning to in-person. This is a solution which I recommend in the strongest possible terms.

Virtual lessons are inherently less efficient than in-person ones (due to a variety of technical and physical restrictions), but I found that I was able to extract immense value from virtual lessons anyway. The ability to play using USB microphones improved lesson quality significantly, and I found that my instructor and I were able to communicate well despite the difficulties of holding a lesson over Zoom. The greatest improvement would be, of course, in-person lessons. It is critical that they are reinstated.
Thank you for providing microphones to remote students!
like I said, I think we did the best we could given the required virtual format
I think this course worked as well as a series of Zoom lessons could. There were ways to work around Zoom lag or bad connections when they happened.
The course was run as well as it could have been online
Virtual FaceTime lessons succeeded.
The course was taught through zoom, and Yale had provided microphones for the best recording quality. As such, I thought it was as good as it could have been given the COVID restrictions.
Virtual lessons are not efficient. There are ways, especially for strings, to have in-person lessons without increasing risk of infection (more for Yale College admin than for individual teachers)

I am very appreciative that the Music department provided microphones that could be used for our lessons. Previously, I did not have a microphone, and my audio quality significantly improved afterwards.

Instructor usage of the Zoom platform, coupled with CleanFeed, was surprisingly good considering the virtual circumstances. (The School of Music made desktop computers and microphones available in the practice rooms, but I chose to use my own setup with the microphone that the bands had given me).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Your experience with the course will depend on your interests and your instrument, but if you love performing music then by all means apply for lessons.

I would recommend this course to any student who takes his/her/their musicianship seriously. The amount of value that a student will take out of this course is directly proportional to the amount of work that student is willing to put in. Given regular practice and consistent open-mindedness, taking this course is an incredible asset.
Yes absolutely, if you want to dedicate a reasonable amount of time to improving yourself as a musician and you are willing to be receptive to new ideas and suggestions!
YSM students are very knowledgeable and I had a great teacher! Learned so much!
Yes, if you want to take lessons!
Absolutely
Yes! If you're looking for a conservatory-style music education, definitely take Lessons for Credit.
Yes. If you enjoy playing music, this course was excellent. Of course, your experience will be determined by the individual professor you study with. That said, I highly recommend it.
Yes!!! Im a political science major and am going to law school. I took this lesson spring of senior year and Im so happy that I did!! Such a fun, helpful, and satisfying experience.
Yes. Taking lessons with a faculty member is a great experience where you get to improve your musical skills.
If they would like the chance to work with a YSM professor and enhance their musical performance skills.
Yes!
Yes--it is a great privilege to play and study music here at Yale.

Virtual private lessons.
Virtual music lessons
Virtual private lessons. A couple of in-person coachings before my recital.
Virtual lesson
We had a remote, synchronous concert at the end of the year.
Music lesson

In person one-on-one
